sen.j: 三島 通庸（みしま みちつね、1835年6月26日（天保6年6月1日 (旧暦)） - 1888年（明治21年）10月23日）は、日本の武士・薩摩藩士、内務省 (日本)官僚。
sen.e: Michitsune MISHIMA (June 26, 1835 - October 23, 1888) was a Japanese samurai who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan and a bureaucrat in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.
Michitsune MISHIMA (June 26, 1835 - October 23, 1888) was a Japanese samurai who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan and a bureaucrat in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.
Michitsune MISHIMA (June 26, 1835 - October 23, 1888) was a Japanese samurai who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan and a bureaucrat in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.

sen.j: 子爵。
sen.e: He was a viscount.
He was a viscount.
He was a viscount.

sen.j: 仮名 (通称)は弥兵衛。
sen.e: His kemyo (assumed name) (common name) was Yahei.
His kemyo (assumed name) (common name) was Yahei.
His kemyo (assumed name) (common name) was Yahei.

sen.j: 県令時代は、住民の反対を押し切り強引に土木工事を進める手法から、「土木県令」や「鬼県令」の俗称で呼ばれた。
sen.e: When he was at office of Kenrei (prefectural governor), he was called with a familiar name of 'Kenrei of public work' or 'Oni (ogre) Kenrei', as he aggressively pushed public works (engineering works) ahead over residents' opposition.

When he was at office of Kenrei (prefectural governor), he was called with a familiar name of 'Kenrei of public work' or 'Oni (ogre) Kenrei', as he aggressively pushed public works (engineering works) ahead over residents' opposition.

When he was at office of Kenrei (prefectural governor), he was called with a familiar name of 'Kenrei of public work' or 'Oni (ogre) Kenrei', as he aggressively pushed public works (engineering works) ahead over residents' opposition.

sen.j: 薩摩藩士・三島通純の長男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the eldest child of Michizumi MISHIMA who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan.
He was born as the eldest child of Michizumi MISHIMA who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan.
He was born as the eldest child of Michizumi MISHIMA who was a feudal retainer of Satsuma clan.

sen.j: 三島家は代々藩の鼓指南役の家柄であったが、通庸は飽き足らずに示現流を学ぶとともに伊地知正治より兵学を学んだ。
sen.e: Mishima family had been a family lineage of domain's instructor of tsuzumi (drum) for generations but it was inadequate for Michitsune, and he studied military science under Masaharu IJICHI as well as learning Jigenryu school (one of ancient kenjutsu (swordplay) styles passed down in Satsuma Domain and neighboring area).

The Mishima family had a long tradition of being the domain's instructor of tsuzumi (drum) for generations but it was unsatisfactory for Michitsune, and he studied military science under Masaharu IJICHI as well as learning Jigenryu school (one of ancient kenjutsu (swordplay) styles passed down in Satsuma Domain and neighboring area).
sen.cmt: 原文の意味が通じるように修正しました。
sen.e: The Mishima family had a long tradition of being the domain's instructor of tsuzumi (drum) for generations but it was unsatisfactory for Michitsune, and he studied military science under Masaharu IJICHI as well as learning Jigenryu school (one of ancient kenjutsu (swordplay) styles passed down in Satsuma Domain and neighboring area).

sen.j: 寺田屋事件に関与して謹慎を命じられる。
sen.e: He involved in the Teradaya Incident and was confined to his house.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was involved in the Teradaya Incident and ordered to be confined to his house.
He was involved in the Teradaya Incident and ordered to be confined to his house.

sen.j: しかし、のちに藩主島津忠義によって人馬奉行に抜擢され、鳥羽伏見の戦いでは小荷駄隊を率いて活躍した。
sen.e: However, he was selected for Jinba Bugyo (Magistrate of inspection of battleground, and deployment and positioning of military capability) by the lord of domain Tadayoshi SHIMAZU and he showed remarkable service in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi leading konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, he was selected for Jinba Bugyo (Magistrate of inspection of battleground, and deployment and positioning of military capability) by the lord of the domain, Tadayoshi SHIMAZU and he showed remarkable service in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, leading konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies).

However, he was selected for Jinba Bugyo (Magistrate of inspection of battleground, and deployment and positioning of military capability) by the lord of the domain, Tadayoshi SHIMAZU and he showed remarkable service in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi, leading konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies).

sen.j: 戊辰戦争後は藩政改革に参加し、民事奉行や日向都城市の地頭など不平士族等を治める功績を残した。
sen.e: After the Boshin War, he filled posts of Minji Bugyo (Magistrate of civil affair) and Jito (manager and lord of manor) of Miyakonojo City, Hyuga Province and he participated in reformation of domain duties and performed great services in society controlling fuhei shizoku (former samurai with gripes).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the Boshin War, he filled posts of Minji Bugyo (Magistrate of civil affair) and Jito (manager and lord of manor) of Miyakonojo City, Hyuga Province and he participated in reformation of domain duties and performed great services in society controlling fuhei shizoku (former samurai with gripes).

After the Boshin War, he filled posts of Minji Bugyo (Magistrate of civil affair) and Jito (manager and lord of manor) of Miyakonojo City, Hyuga Province and he participated in reformation of domain duties and performed great services in society controlling fuhei shizoku (former samurai with gripes).

sen.j: これを見込んだ大久保利通の計らいで新政府に出仕する事になる。
sen.e: His achievements won confidence and he attended at the new government with arrangement of Toshimichi OKUBO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His achievements won confidence and he attended at the new government with arrangement of Toshimichi OKUBO.
His achievements won confidence and he attended at the new government with arrangement of Toshimichi OKUBO.

sen.j: 東京府職員（参事）から教部省（大丞）を皮切りに、酒田県・山形県・福島県・栃木県の各県令、内務省 (日本)土木局長（県令と兼任）、警視総監を歴任した。
sen.e: Starting with a personnel in Tokyo-fu Prefecture (a councilor) to a Taijo (Senior Secretary) in Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion), he successively filled posts of Kenrei of several prefectures, including Sakata Prefecture, Yamagata Prefecture, Fukushima Prefecture and Tochigi Prefecture, the head of engineering bureau (served concurrently as Kenrei) in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) and the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.

Starting with a personnel in Tokyo-fu Prefecture (a councilor) to a Taijo (Senior Secretary) in Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion), he successively filled posts of Kenrei of several prefectures, including Sakata Prefecture, Yamagata Prefecture, Fukushima Prefecture and Tochigi Prefecture, the head of engineering bureau (served concurrently as Kenrei) in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) and the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.

Starting with a personnel in Tokyo-fu Prefecture (a councilor) to a Taijo (Senior Secretary) in Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion), he successively filled posts of Kenrei of several prefectures, including Sakata Prefecture, Yamagata Prefecture, Fukushima Prefecture and Tochigi Prefecture, the head of engineering bureau (served concurrently as Kenrei) in prewar Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) and the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.

sen.j: 東京府にて銀座煉瓦街建設の大任を果たした。
sen.e: He carried out a great task of constructing Ginza Renga-gai (brick town or brick street) in Tokyo-fu Prefecture.
He carried out a great task of constructing Ginza Renga-gai (brick town or brick street) in Tokyo-fu Prefecture.
He carried out a great task of constructing Ginza Renga-gai (brick town or brick street) in Tokyo-fu Prefecture.

sen.j: 1887年、維新の功により子爵を授けられた。
sen.e: In 1887, he received rank of viscount for his service to the Restoration.
In 1887, he received rank of viscount for his service during the Restoration.
In 1887, he received rank of viscount for his service during the Restoration.

sen.j: 1874年（明治7年）に酒田県令に就任する。
sen.e: In 1874, he was appointed to Kenrei of Sakata Prefecture.
In 1874, he was appointed to Kenrei of Sakata Prefecture.
In 1874, he was appointed to Kenrei of Sakata Prefecture.

sen.j: 着任早々の課題は、ワッパ騒動と呼ばれる農民抗議への対策であった。
sen.e: The immediate issue he had to attend when he was appointed to the post was to take a measure towards Wappa Disturbance, which was a protest of peasants.
The immediate issue he had to attend when he was appointed to the post was to take a measure towards Wappa Disturbance, which was a protest of peasants.
The immediate issue he had to attend when he was appointed to the post was to take a measure towards Wappa Disturbance, which was a protest of peasants.

sen.j: これは、旧藩時代からの県令や官吏が、中央の布告を無視して旧藩時代同様の税と労役を課したことに対する農民の反抗であった。
sen.e: The protest was against Kenrei and government officials from former feudal domain, who imposed tax and royaku (labor service) no different from former feudal domain period ignoring a proclamation from central.

The protest was against Kenrei and government officials from former feudal domain, who imposed tax and royaku (labor service) no different from former feudal domain period, ignoring a proclamation by the central government.

The protest was against Kenrei and government officials from former feudal domain, who imposed tax and royaku (labor service) no different from former feudal domain period, ignoring a proclamation by the central government.

sen.j: 三島は官吏を全面的に更迭するとともに、農民に対しては弾圧で臨んだ。
sen.e: He challenged at the issue by reshuffling government officials completely and oppressing peasants.
He challenged at the issue by reshuffling government officials completely and oppressing peasants.
He challenged at the issue by reshuffling government officials completely and oppressing peasants.

sen.j: 翌年、裁判により過納金を農民に返すことで騒動は決着した。
sen.e: Next year, the issue came to an end in a court by returning overpayments to peasants.
Next year, the issue came to an end in court by returning overpayments to peasants.
Next year, the issue came to an end in court by returning overpayments to peasants.

sen.j: 酒田県は1875年（明治8年）8月に鶴岡県になり、翌年には山形県・置賜県と合併して山形県となった。
sen.e: In August 1875, Sakata Prefecture became Tsuruoka Prefecture and next year, merged with Yamagata Prefecture and Okitama Prefecture establishing Yamagata Prefecture.
In August 1875, Sakata Prefecture became Tsuruoka Prefecture and in the next year Tsuruoka Prefecture merged with Yamagata Prefecture and Okitama Prefecture to become Yamagata Prefecture.
In August 1875, Sakata Prefecture became Tsuruoka Prefecture and in the next year Tsuruoka Prefecture merged with Yamagata Prefecture and Okitama Prefecture to become Yamagata Prefecture.

sen.j: 三島は新たに鶴岡・山形県の県令に就任する。
sen.e: Mishima was appointed to Kenrei of Tsuruoka and Yamagata Prefecture.
MISHIMA was appointed Kenrei of Tsuruoka and Yamagata Prefecture.
MISHIMA was appointed Kenrei of Tsuruoka and Yamagata Prefecture.

sen.j: 山形における政策の中心は、道路・橋梁整備と公共施設の建築であった。
sen.e: Central policies when he was at Kenrei of Yamagata Prefecture were road and bridge development, and construction of public facilities.
The focus of the policies established when he was the Kenrei of Yamagata Prefecture was road and bridge development and construction of public facilities.
The focus of the policies established when he was the Kenrei of Yamagata Prefecture was road and bridge development and construction of public facilities.

sen.j: 江戸時代までの山形地域は、日本海と最上川を経由する舟運により、江戸よりも大坂と強く結びついていた。
sen.e: Yamagata region had stronger connection to Osaka rather than to Tokyo until the end of Edo period, through ship transportation via Japan Sea and Mogami-gawa River.
Yamagata region had stronger connections with Osaka rather than with Tokyo until the end of Edo period, through ship transportation via the Sea of Japan and Mogami-gawa River.
Yamagata region had stronger connections with Osaka rather than with Tokyo until the end of Edo period, through ship transportation via the Sea of Japan and Mogami-gawa River.

sen.j: しかし明治時代に陸運が重視されると、陸路による東京までの交通整備が進められた。
sen.e: However land transportation was taken seriously in Meiji period and land routes to Tokyo were developed.
However, when land transportation became important in Meiji period, land routes to Tokyo were developed.
However, when land transportation became important in Meiji period, land routes to Tokyo were developed.

sen.j: 1880年（明治13年）に米沢、福島間に萬世大路こと栗子街道を、1882年（明治15年）には山形、仙台間に関山街道を完成させた。
sen.e: Construction of Kuriko-kaido Road, called Bansei Tairo (a main throughfare) that connects Yonezawa and Fukushima was finished in 1880, and Sekiyama-kaido Road that connects Yamagata and Sendai was finished in 1882.

Construction of Kuriko-kaido Road, called Bansei Tairo (a main thoroughfare) that connected Yonezawa and Fukushima was finished in 1880, and Sekiyama-kaido Road that connected Yamagata and Sendai was finished in 1882.

Construction of Kuriko-kaido Road, called Bansei Tairo (a main thoroughfare) that connected Yonezawa and Fukushima was finished in 1880, and Sekiyama-kaido Road that connected Yamagata and Sendai was finished in 1882.

sen.j: この両道は、馬車が通行可能な規格で作られた。
sen.e: Both roads were build in a standard allows a horse-drawn buggy to pass through.
Both roads were build conforming the standard that allowed buggies to pass through.
Both roads were build conforming the standard that allowed buggies to pass through.

sen.j: こうして山形県の産物が陸路で福島や仙台に出て、ついで奥州街道や鉄道による東京への輸送路が確立した。
sen.e: Products of Yamagata was trasported to Fukushima and Sendai via land transportation and then trasport routes to Tokyo, such as Oshu-kaido Road and railway, were established.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Products of Yamagata were transported to Fukushima and Sendai via land transportation and then transport routes to Tokyo, such as Oshu-kaido Road and railway, were established.
Products of Yamagata were transported to Fukushima and Sendai via land transportation and then transport routes to Tokyo, such as Oshu-kaido Road and railway, were established.

sen.j: 結果、県経済は活況を呈した。
sen.e: As a result, economics of the prefecture grew lively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: As a result, economics of the prefecture grew lively.
As a result, economics of the prefecture grew lively.

sen.j: 三島は、他にも隣県に通じる車馬通行可能な道路をいくつも建設した。
sen.e: Mishima also constructed many roads that horse-drawn buggy can go pass connecting to neighboring prefectures.
MISHIMA also constructed many other roads that horse-drawn buggies could pass, connecting Yamagata to neighboring prefectures.
MISHIMA also constructed many other roads that horse-drawn buggies could pass, connecting Yamagata to neighboring prefectures.

sen.j: 栗子山隧道（後の栗子トンネル）、関山隧道（関山トンネル）等のトンネル工事、多数の橋梁工事が行われた。
sen.e: Tunnel construction works, including Kurikoyama-zuido Tunnel (later Kurikoyama Tunnel) and Sekiyama-zuido Tunnel (Sekiyama Tunnel), and many bridge construction works were carried out.
Tunnel construction works, including Kurikoyama-zuido Tunnel (later Kuriko Tunnel) and Sekiyama-zuido Tunnel (Sekiyama Tunnel), and many bridge construction works were carried out.
sen.cmt: 読み方の間違いを訂正しました。
sen.e: Tunnel construction works, including Kurikoyama-zuido Tunnel (later Kuriko Tunnel) and Sekiyama-zuido Tunnel (Sekiyama Tunnel), and many bridge construction works were carried out.

sen.j: また、羽州街道の酢川（現：須川 (山形県)）に石造の常磐橋 (山形県)を作った。
sen.e: Also Tokiwa-bashi Bridge (Yamagata Prefecture) was constructed over Su-kawa (酢川) River (present Su-kawa (須川) River (Yamagata Prefecture)) at Ushu-kaido Road.
Also Tokiwa-bashi Bridge (Yamagata Prefecture) was constructed over Su-kawa (酢川) River (present Su-kawa (須川) River (Yamagata Prefecture)) at Ushu-kaido Road.
Also Tokiwa-bashi Bridge (Yamagata Prefecture) was constructed over Su-kawa (酢川) River (present Su-kawa (須川) River (Yamagata Prefecture)) at Ushu-kaido Road.

sen.j: これらの道は現在の国道になっている。
sen.e: These roads are present national highways.
These roads are national highways today.
These roads are national highways today.

sen.j: 建築では、県庁・病院・学校などを当時としては大きな規模で多数作った。
sen.e: For architectures, he constructed many buildings in large scale for the time, such as a prefectural office, hospital and schools.
For architectures, he constructed many buildings in large scale for the time, such as prefectural offices, hospitals and schools.
For architectures, he constructed many buildings in large scale for the time, such as prefectural offices, hospitals and schools.

sen.j: 現存するものに旧済生館病院本館（重要文化財）・旧東村山郡役所・旧東田川郡役所。
sen.e: The main building of formar Saiseikan hospital (important cultural heritage), formar government office of Higashimurayama County and formar government office of Higashitagawa County are still existing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The main building of former Saiseikan Hospital (important cultural heritage), former government office of Higashimurayama County and former government office of Higashitagawa County still exist today.

The main building of former Saiseikan Hospital (important cultural heritage), former government office of Higashimurayama County and former government office of Higashitagawa County still exist today.

sen.j: 現存しないものでは山形県庁舎、鶴岡の朝暘学校などがある。
sen.e: Yamagata Prefectural office and Choyo-gakko School in Tsuruoka do not exist anymore.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Yamagata Prefectural office and Choyo-gakko School in Tsuruoka do not exist anymore.
Yamagata Prefectural office and Choyo-gakko School in Tsuruoka do not exist anymore.

sen.j: これらは擬洋風建築で建てられた。
sen.e: These buildings were built in Gi-yofu architecture (imitative Western-style architecture) style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: These buildings were built in Gi-yofu architecture (imitative Western-style architecture) style.
These buildings were built in Gi-yofu architecture (imitative Western-style architecture) style.

sen.j: 作業に従事した棟梁たちがその後も形式を踏襲したため、東北地方には多数の擬洋風建築が存在することとなった。
sen.e: There are many buildings built in Gi-yofu architecture in Tohoku region, as toryo (master builder) who engaged in the constructions followed the same style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There are many buildings built in Gi-yofu architecture in Tohoku region, as toryo (master builder) who engaged in the constructions followed the same style.
There are many buildings built in Gi-yofu architecture in Tohoku region, as toryo (master builder) who engaged in the constructions followed the same style.

sen.j: 三島は洋画家高橋由一を援助し、自らが作らせた建築物や都市の景観を絵に描かせて業績を誇った。
sen.e: Mishima supported a Western-style painter Yuichi TAKAHASHI and made Yuichi paint pictures of architectures and view of the city that he constructed to pride himself on his achievements.
Mishima supported a Western-style painter Yuichi TAKAHASHI and made Yuichi paint pictures of architectures and view of the city that he constructed to pride himself on his achievements.
Mishima supported a Western-style painter Yuichi TAKAHASHI and made Yuichi paint pictures of architectures and view of the city that he constructed to pride himself on his achievements.

sen.j: 三島は人民に対しては傲岸な態度で臨み、強引な課税や労役賦課、寄付金強要を行なうなど、批判に対しては弾圧一辺倒であった。
sen.e: Mishima faced to the people with arrogance and measure against criticism was nothing else but oppression, such as forcible taxation and imposition of royaku (labor service) and demanding for donations.

MISHIMA was arrogant toward the people and the measures he took against criticism were nothing but oppression, such as forcible taxation, the imposition of royaku (labor service) and forcing donations.

MISHIMA was arrogant toward the people and the measures he took against criticism were nothing but oppression, such as forcible taxation, the imposition of royaku (labor service) and forcing donations.

sen.j: 1882年（明治15年）、自由民権運動を推進する自由党勢力が盛んな福島県に県令として着任して弾圧を開始した。
sen.e: In 1882, he was appointed to Kenrei of Fukushima Prefecture where power of Liberal Party, which promotes Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), was active and he started oppression.

In 1882, he was appointed to Kenrei of Fukushima Prefecture where power of Liberal Party, which promoted Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), was enormous and he started oppression.

In 1882, he was appointed to Kenrei of Fukushima Prefecture where power of Liberal Party, which promoted Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), was enormous and he started oppression.

sen.j: 越後街道、会津街道、山形街道の3つの街道を建設を推進した。
sen.e: He promoted construction of three roads, Echigo-kaido Road, Aizu-kaido Road and Yamagata-kaido Road.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He promoted construction of three roads, Echigo-kaido Road, Aizu-kaido Road and Yamagata-kaido Road.
He promoted construction of three roads, Echigo-kaido Road, Aizu-kaido Road and Yamagata-kaido Road.

sen.j: そして建設のための重税や労役を義務付け、また道路用地を収用などの負担を強いた。
sen.e: He imposed heavy taxation and royaku compulsory and expropriated land for roads for construction.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He imposed heavy taxation and compulsory royaku and expropriated land for road construction.
He imposed heavy taxation and compulsory royaku and expropriated land for road construction.

sen.j: 道路は完成したものの、陸運の中心が鉄道に切り替わったために街道整備は時代遅れになっていた。
sen.e: Although construction of roads were completed, majority of land transportation shifted to railways and roads development became out of date.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Although the construction of the roads were completed, the mainstay of land transportation had already shifted to railways and road development became out of date.
Although the construction of the roads were completed, the mainstay of land transportation had already shifted to railways and road development became out of date.

sen.j: しかし、道路建設は自由党弾圧の口実になった。
sen.e: However construction of roads became the excuse of oppression of Liberal Party.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However construction of roads became the excuse of oppression of Liberal Party.
However construction of roads became the excuse of oppression of Liberal Party.

sen.j: 三島は帝政党を作って自由党との対決を激化させた。
sen.e: Mishima established Constitutional Monarchy Party and intensified confrontation against Liberal Party.
sen.cmt: 帝政党は立憲帝政党のことです。
sen.e: Mishima established Constitutional Monarchy Party and intensified confrontation against Liberal Party.
Mishima established Constitutional Monarchy Party and intensified confrontation against Liberal Party.

sen.j: 自由党の首領・河野広中は激発を戒めたが、ついに福島事件で逮捕・投獄された。
sen.e: A chieftain of Liberal Party, Hironaka KONO banned a protest movement but he finally was arrested and imprisoned because of Fukushima Incident.
The then chieftain of Liberal Party, Hironaka KONO banned outright confrontation, but he finally was arrested and imprisoned because of Fukushima Incident.
The then chieftain of Liberal Party, Hironaka KONO banned outright confrontation, but he finally was arrested and imprisoned because of Fukushima Incident.

sen.j: 栃木県令時代（1884年）、自由党員が三島の暗殺を謀った加波山事件が起こった。
sen.e: While he was taking office as Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture (1884), Kabasan Incident, which Liberal Party member plotted assassination of Mishima, happened.
While he was taking office as Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture (1884), Kabasan Incident, where a Liberal Party member plotted assassination of MISHIMA, happened.
While he was taking office as Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture (1884), Kabasan Incident, where a Liberal Party member plotted assassination of MISHIMA, happened.

sen.j: このことからも、三島による弾圧がいかに自由民権運動にとって障害となっていたかを窺うことができる。
sen.e: The incident tells that Mishima's oppression was a barrier to Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right).
The incident tells that Mishima's oppression was a formidable barrier to Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right).
sen.cmt: 英語の意味を正確に反映するために修正しました
sen.e: The incident tells that Mishima's oppression was a formidable barrier to Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right).

sen.j: 1887年（明治20年）12月25日、三大事件建白運動や大同団結運動など自由民権運動の高揚に対し、皇居付近から「危険人物」を排除する事を目的とした保安条例が勅令によって公布された。
sen.e: On December 25, 1887, hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order), which aimed to remove 'security risk' from neighboring area of Imperial Palace was issued as an imperial edict, as Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), including Daido Danketsu Movement and Sandai Jiken Kenpaku Movement, heated up.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On December 25, 1887, hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order), which aimed to remove 'security risk' from neighboring area of Imperial Palace was issued as an imperial edict, as Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), including Daido Danketsu Movement and Sandai Jiken Kenpaku Movement, heated up.

On December 25, 1887, hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order), which aimed to remove 'security risk' from neighboring area of Imperial Palace was issued as an imperial edict, as Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right), including Daido Danketsu Movement and Sandai Jiken Kenpaku Movement, heated up.

sen.j: すると、警視総監として即日施行した。
sen.e: Mishima enforced it on the very day as the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: MISHIMA enforced it on the very day as Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner.
MISHIMA enforced it on the very day as Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner.

sen.j: 当時の首相伊藤博文は条例に反対であり、内務大臣 (日本)山縣有朋も消極的な態度であったものの、三島は条例を積極的に推進していたとされる。
sen.e: Prime Minister of the time Hirobumi ITO was against the regulation and Minister of Home Affairs (Japan) Aritomo YAMAGATA was also taking passive stand, however Mishima actively promoted the regulation.
Prime Minister of the time, Hirobumi ITO was against the regulation and Minister of Home Affairs (Japan), Aritomo YAMAGATA was also taking passive stand, but Mishima actively promoted the regulation.
sen.cmt: 文法(howeverの語法）を修正しました。
sen.e: Prime Minister of the time, Hirobumi ITO was against the regulation and Minister of Home Affairs (Japan), Aritomo YAMAGATA was also taking passive stand, but Mishima actively promoted the regulation.

sen.j: 弾圧の対象人物に尾崎行雄、片岡健吉、中江兆民、星亨などがいた。
sen.e: Targets of the oppression included Yukio OZAKI, Kenkichi KATAOKA and Chomin NAKAE.
Targets of the oppression included Yukio OZAKI, Kenkichi KATAOKA, Chomin NAKAE and Toru HOSHI
sen.cmt: 訳し漏れを補足しました。
sen.e: Targets of the oppression included Yukio OZAKI, Kenkichi KATAOKA, Chomin NAKAE and Toru HOSHI

sen.j: 地方の開墾に熱意を示し、栃木県那須野ヶ原の肇耕社（後の三島農場）を開設した。
sen.e: He was enthusiastic about cultivation of the provinces and he established Chokosha (later Mishima farm) in Nasunogahara, Tochigi Prefecture.
He was enthusiastic about cultivation of provinces and he established Chokosha (later Mishima Farm) in Nasunogahara, Tochigi Prefecture.
He was enthusiastic about cultivation of provinces and he established Chokosha (later Mishima Farm) in Nasunogahara, Tochigi Prefecture.

sen.j: 弥太郎を社長、親交の深い部下14名を株主として入植者を募集して開墾に従事させた。
sen.e: He made Yataro as a President and his 14 followers, who had close relationship with him, as shareholders, and raised immigrant for cultivation.
Making his eldest son, Yataro President and his 14 followers, who had close relationship with him, shareholders, he recruited immigrants who would live in the provinces and cultivate.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味をきちんと反映できるように修正しました。
sen.e: Making his eldest son, Yataro President and his 14 followers, who had close relationship with him, shareholders, he recruited immigrants who would live in the provinces and cultivate.

sen.j: 現在の那須塩原市三島に別荘を構えた。
sen.e: He set up a villa in present Mishima, Nasushiobara City.
He set up a villa in present Mishima, Nasushiobara City.
He set up a villa in present Mishima, Nasushiobara City.

sen.j: 当時の区割りが現在も残っており、古くからの住人には開墾当初の入植者の子孫が多い。
sen.e: Demarcation of the time still remains and many of residents, who lived there for long time, are descendants of immigrants from start of cultivation.
Demarcation of the time still remains and many of residents, who lived there for long time, are descendants of immigrants from the start of the cultivation.
Demarcation of the time still remains and many of residents, who lived there for long time, are descendants of immigrants from the start of the cultivation.

sen.j: 近年設置された那須野が原博物館の敷地には、開墾に必須であった那須疎水も再現されている。
sen.e: Nasu canal, which was essential to the cultivation, was reconstructed in the site of Nasunogahara Museum that founded recently.
Nasu canal, which was essential to the cultivation, was recreated in the premises of Nasunogahara Museum founded recently.
Nasu canal, which was essential to the cultivation, was recreated in the premises of Nasunogahara Museum founded recently.

sen.j: 栃木県令時代の1884年、三島は塩原街道を開発整備し、同時に塩原に別荘を構えた。
sen.e: In 1884, while he was at Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture, Mishima developed Shiobara-kaido Road and built a villa at the same time.
In 1884, while he was the Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture, MISHIMA developed Shiobara-kaido Road and built a villa in Shiobara at the same time.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味が伝わるように修正しました。
sen.e: In 1884, while he was the Kenrei of Tochigi Prefecture, MISHIMA developed Shiobara-kaido Road and built a villa in Shiobara at the same time.

sen.j: 1902年、皇太子時代の大正天皇は初めて塩原を訪れた。
sen.e: In 1902, Emperor Taisho, who was still he Crown Prince then, visited Shiobara for the first time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1902, Emperor Taisho, who was still the Crown Prince then, visited Shiobara for the first time.
sen.cmt: スペルミスを修正しました。
sen.e: In 1902, Emperor Taisho, who was still the Crown Prince then, visited Shiobara for the first time.

sen.j: 三島別荘等に遊んで温泉や風光に感銘を受けられた。
sen.e: He stayed in Mishima's villa and was profoundly impressed with hot spring and beautiful scenery.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He stayed in Mishima's villa and was profoundly impressed with hot spring and beautiful scenery.
He stayed in Mishima's villa and was profoundly impressed with hot spring and beautiful scenery.

sen.j: これを契機として1904年、三島子爵家は別荘を献上して「塩原御用邸」となり、主に避暑のため愛用された。
sen.e: Taking this opportunity, viscount Mishima presented the villa in 1904 as 'Shiobara Goyotei' and it was used for summer exodus.
Taking this opportunity, Viscount Mishima presented the villa to the Imperial Family in 1904 and it came to be called 'Shiobara Goyotei' and used mainly for summer exodus of the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味をきちんと反映できるように修正しました。
sen.e: Taking this opportunity, Viscount Mishima presented the villa to the Imperial Family in 1904 and it came to be called 'Shiobara Goyotei' and used mainly for summer exodus of the Imperial Family.

sen.j: 1948年に厚生省所管の厚生施設として下賜され、現在の跡地は国立塩原視力障害センターとして利用されている。
sen.e: In 1948, the villa was granted as an Imperial gift for a welfare facility of Ministry of Health and Welfare, and presently the site is used as National Shiobara Visual Disabilities Institution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1948, the villa was granted as an Imperial gift for a welfare facility of Ministry of Health and Welfare, and presently the site is used as National Shiobara Visual Disabilities Institution.
In 1948, the villa was granted as an Imperial gift for a welfare facility of Ministry of Health and Welfare, and presently the site is used as National Shiobara Visual Disabilities Institution.

sen.j: 旧御座所のみ移築されて「天皇の間記念公園」（栃木県有形文化）として公開されている。
sen.e: Only former Gozasho (a room for a noble person) was relocated and reconstructed as 'Emperor's Room Memorial Park' (a tangible cultural asset designated by Tochigi Prefecture) and is opened to public.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Only former Gozasho (a room for a noble person) was relocated and reconstructed as 'Emperor's Room Memorial Park' (a tangible cultural asset designated by Tochigi Prefecture) and is opened to public.
Only former Gozasho (a room for a noble person) was relocated and reconstructed as 'Emperor's Room Memorial Park' (a tangible cultural asset designated by Tochigi Prefecture) and is opened to public.

sen.j: 1888年（明治21年）夏、警視総監在任中の三島は病に倒れた。
sen.e: Summer 1888, Mishima was down by an illness while he was taking office at the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.
In the summer of 1888, during his tenure as the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner, MISHIMA fell ill.
sen.cmt: 英語としてより自然な表現に修正しました。
sen.e: In the summer of 1888, during his tenure as the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner, MISHIMA fell ill.

sen.j: そして同年10月23日、見舞いに訪れた多くの部下・友人たちに見取られこの世を去った。
sen.e: Many friends and followers gathered to pay their last tribute to him and he passed away on October 23, 1888.
Many friends and followers gathered to pay their last tribute to him and he passed away on October 23, 1888.
Many friends and followers gathered to pay their last tribute to him and he passed away on October 23, 1888.

sen.j: 在任中に死去したのは三島のみである。
sen.e: Mishima is the only one who died while he was at the post of the Tokyo Metropolitan Police commissioner.
MISHIMA is the only Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner who died during his term of office.
sen.cmt: 英語としてより自然な表現に修正しました。
sen.e: MISHIMA is the only Tokyo Metropolitan Police Commissioner who died during his term of office.

sen.j: 葬儀には1万2千名が参列し、青山墓地に埋葬された。
sen.e: 12000 people attended his funeral and he was buried in Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.
12000 people attended his funeral and he was buried in Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.
12000 people attended his funeral and he was buried in Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.

sen.j: 入院から死の当日までの見舞い客、葬儀・1周忌の参列者まで一人ひとりの名前が記録されている。
sen.e: Every single people's names, who visited to him in the hospital between the day of hospitalization to the day he died, and attendee of funeral ceremony and ceremony of the first anniversary of his death, were recorded.

The names of every single person who visited him in the hospital from the day of hospitalization to the day of his death as well as every attendee of the funeral and the first anniversary ceremony of his death, are recorded.
sen.cmt: 英語としてより自然な表現に修正しました。
sen.e: The names of every single person who visited him in the hospital from the day of hospitalization to the day of his death as well as every attendee of the funeral and the first anniversary ceremony of his death, are recorded.

sen.j: 二女峰子は大久保の次男牧野伸顕に嫁いだ（牧野伸顕の娘雪子は吉田茂に嫁いでおり、従って麻生太郎は来孫にあたる）。
sen.e: His second daughter Mineko got married to second son of Okubo, Nobuaki MAKINO (daughter of Nobuaki MAKINO, Yukiko, got married to Shigeru YOSHIDA therefore Taro ASO is his great-great-great-grandchild).

His second daughter, Mineko got married to the second son of OKUBO, Nobuaki MAKINO (whose daughter, Yukiko got married to Shigeru YOSHIDA and therefore Taro ASO is MAKINO's great-great-great-grandchild).
sen.cmt: 英語としてより自然な表現に修正しました。
sen.e: His second daughter, Mineko got married to the second son of OKUBO, Nobuaki MAKINO (whose daughter, Yukiko got married to Shigeru YOSHIDA and therefore Taro ASO is MAKINO's great-great-great-grandchild).

sen.j: 長男三島彌太郎は第8代日本銀行総裁、三男の三島弥彦は日本初のオリンピック代表選手、孫の三島通陽は第4代ボーイスカウト日本連盟総長を務めた。
sen.e: His eldest son Yataro MISHIMA became the eighth Governor of the Bank of Japan, his third son Yahiko MISHIMA became Japan's first members of an Olympic team and his grand son Michiharu MISHIMA became the fourth President of Scout Association of Japan.

His eldest son Yataro MISHIMA became the eighth Governor of the Bank of Japan, his third son Yahiko MISHIMA became a member of the Japan's first Olympic team and his grand son Michiharu MISHIMA became the fourth President of Scout Association of Japan.

His eldest son Yataro MISHIMA became the eighth Governor of the Bank of Japan, his third son Yahiko MISHIMA became a member of the Japan's first Olympic team and his grand son Michiharu MISHIMA became the fourth President of Scout Association of Japan.
